tool.name: Tool

param.name: select_raster
param.dialogReference:
Browse to a raster layer.

Note: this will cause a temporary error but this will go away when a feature layer is chosen as output for the last input parameter !!!

param.name: num_classes
param.dialogReference: Enter the number of classes for classification.

param.name: num_cells
param.displayname: Enter minimum number of cells to make a valid class
param.dialogReference: Enter the number to represent the minimum number of cells to make a valid class.

param.name: output_location
param.dialogReference: Browse to the location where the file will be stored and enter the file name for the feature layer that will be outputted by the tool.

tool.summary:
This is a Python toolbox that requires 4 parameters to be inputted by the user. The first parameter requires browsing to a raster layer. The second parameter requires entering the number of classes for classification. The third parameter requires entering the number to represent the minimum number of cells to make a valid class. The fourth parameter requires the distination path with file name to save the feature layer that is outputted by the tool.

Once the tool is running it uses the parameters entered by the user to perform an unsupervised classification using the arcpy tool IsoClusterUnsupervisedClassification. The result, which is a raster layer is then converted to a feature layer using the arcpy tool RasterToPolygon_conversion, which saves it to the output destination entered by the user.
tool.usage: To classify a raster layer using unsupervised classification and save the result as a feature layer.

The fourth parameter requires the distination path with file name to save the feature layer that is outputted by the tool.

Once the tool is running it uses the parameters entered by the user to perform an unsupervised classification using the arcpy tool IsoClusterUnsupervisedClassification. The result, which is a raster layer is then converted to a feature layer using the arcpy tool RasterToPolygon_conversion, which saves it to the output destination entered by the user.
